title: THE BEGINNING
subtitle: Where it all started
_note: Chapter 1 card - DM Champ section
'My first project was DM Champ. It's an AI sales agent.'
Product name callout on mention
'You connect it to WhatsApp, Instagram...Closes deals, makes about 100 grand a year'
Revenue stat overlay - big impact number
'Now DM Champ already existed when I started using Claude Code'
Key concept callout - working on existing code
'existing code base. Code was kind of a mess because it was originally'
'built with a no-code tool called FlutterFlow. And then we exported it'
PEXELS: Close-up code on screen - existing codebase context
SCREEN 02: Terminal running claude, scanning repo - 'open the repo and run Claude Code'
'just init and go. Did it break stuff? Yeah but so do normal developers'
'That's not a Claude Code problem. And with the latest models, it barely makes mistakes'
'But here's where it gets interesting. On top of DM Champ I built a separate system'
Number callout on '6 AI agents that handle the entire support pipeline'
SLIDE 02: Flow diagram - bug > triage > fix > notify. 'one agent figures out what's wrong, another writes the fix'
'I wake up, check the fix, approve it. Done. 6 agents, 4 custom MCPs'
Boop on 'done' - punctuate the agent pipeline completion
SCREEN 03: dm-champ-agents repo, src/publish/ with 6 handlers - '6 agents, 4 custom MCPs'
'setup file for this project is just a basic CLAUDE.md explaining the repo'
'Nothing fancy. When you're starting out, you don't need a complex setup. You just need to start'
Key message callout - motivational beat
Whoosh: Chapter transition - The Mistake
Base layer under chapter card 2

title: THE MISTAKE
subtitle: What cost me weeks
_note: Chapter 2 card - the autonomy mistake
'Now here's where most people go wrong. And I made this exact mistake'
'government access control system. Tap to enter badges, admin dashboard, mobile app, the whole thing'
Big number - emphasis on project scale
PEXELS: Person tapping access card on door reader - government project visual
'Let it build everything. Fully autonomous. End to end. No human checking anything'
Punch on 'it does not work' - the big reveal
HOLD on 'it does not work'
GIF: disappointed reaction on 'it does not work'
Release zoom
'I know that's not what you want to hear...everyone telling you to let AI do everything...for anything going into production'
'bottleneck is checking whether the code actually works. Can write tests but basic'
Concept callout - what actually slows you down
'testing the actual interface. What takes you a minute takes the AI 50 minutes. Take screenshots, analyze them'
SLIDE 03: AI builds (speed icon) / Human verifies (eye icon) - 'AI builds fast, human verifies'
'Don't skip the verify step. I tried. It cost me weeks'
'Cost me weeks. But that wasn't even the real lesson. The real lesson was something I stumbled into by accident'
Whoosh: Chapter transition - Structure
Base layer under chapter card 3

title: THE STRUCTURE
subtitle: What changes everything
_note: Chapter 3 card - the structure unlock
'Working on this government project. 27 features across the app. Claude keeps losing context'
Number callout - scale of the project
'doesn't know what a feature is supposed to do. Mixing things up. Code that runs but doesn't fit'
'model isn't stupid. Really smart now. So the problem has to be on my end. So I reorganized everything'
SLIDE 04: Folder tree diagram - each folder labeled (auth, NFC, permissions, cards, locations)
SCREEN 04: VS Code features/ folder expanded, 15 folders - '15 features on the backend'
'one self-contained. But here's the part that made a real difference. Every single feature folder gets its own instruction file'
SCREEN 05: Per-feature CLAUDE.md open, scrolling through - 'what the feature is for, how it works'
Number callout - context files across the project
'when Claude works on the access badge feature, it automatically knows all of that context'
SLIDE 05: Claude + context = clean code (check) / Claude - context = compiles but wrong (X)
Shimmer: 'That was the unlock' - insight reveal
Punch on 'No context? Code that runs but makes no sense'
HOLD zoom on key insight
Release zoom
'The other thing I did is project management inside the repo. Not Jira. Not Linear. Just text files'
SCREEN 06: TASKS/ directory, numbered files with status emojis - '107 task files'
Number callout - task files in markdown
'Why not a real project management tool? Because Claude Code can read local files instantly'
'The moment you make it talk to an external tool through API, it's slower and less reliable'
'Built custom integration with ClickUp, it's still slower than just reading a text file'
Key principle callout - local is king
'than just reading a text file. For an AI, local is king'
'got a SaaS running, government system with proper structure, I figured this out. But then things got a lot bigger'
GIF: 'buckle up here we go' on 'things got a lot bigger'
MID CTA: 'Quick thing. If you're watching this and you want to set up Claude Code for a real project'
'I'm building a community called Claudify. Real builds, not toy projects. Link in description'

subtitle: Link in description
_note: Mid-video CTA overlay - synced to 'community called Claudify'
Whoosh: Major chapter transition - Business OS
Base layer under chapter card 4

title: THE SYSTEM
subtitle: Building a business OS
_note: Chapter 4 card - the business operating system
'the third project isn't even a project. It's my entire business running through Claude Code'
SLIDE 06: Hub diagram - center 'One Repo' with 4 spokes: Consulting, YouTube, SaaS, Client Delivery
Shimmer on hub diagram - synced with file count reveal
Number callout - 1066 files in one repo
SCREEN 07: .mcp.json showing 7 server configs - '7 custom MCP servers'
Number callout on MCP server section
'I built these myself. One checks how brands appear in ChatGPT/Gemini. One does keyword research...'
PEXELS: Server room / data center abstract - visual metaphor for custom servers
'Why build my own? Because the ones other people have made don't do what you need for real work. Every time I hit that wall'
Key principle callout - the pattern of building custom tools
'I ended up building my own. That's the pattern. You can use existing MCPs as a base...open source anyway'
'Now here's the big one. This goes against what basically everyone is saying right now. Everyone talks about giving agents roles'
SLIDE 07: Role agents (meh ~) vs Task agents (check, specific jobs) - the contrarian insight
'doesn't make things noticeably better. They work, they run, but the output isn't really different'
GIF: underwhelmed reaction on 'not really different from just using Claude Code directly'
'What actually makes a difference is giving agent-specific tasks. Not be a developer. It's take this transcript and generate a video timeline'
Key concept callout - task agents over role agents
SCREEN 08: .claude/agents/ folder, 14 agent files
'Each agent gets specific tools and specific context. They do one thing well.'
Big number callout - system scale
'14 of these, plus 24 skills. A skill is a set of instructions for a specific job'
'instead of explaining how to write a video script every time'
Boop on 'one skill per job' - punctuate the point
'Claude just loads the skill and knows exactly what to do. Same for audits, reports, timelines. One skill per job'
'latest evolution is task agents working together in teams. Not one agent calling another'
'Actual teams with a shared task list'
Concept callout - the latest evolution
'produce this video, kicks off a team. One builds timeline, another finds GIFs'
'another one sources stock footage. They're all working in parallel'
Concept callout - agents working in parallel
'off the same task list, coordinating with each other. That feels genuinely new'
'Not managing each agent. They pick up tasks, do their work, report back'
Punch on 'closest thing to having an actual team'
HOLD on 'closest thing to an actual team. When do you use a sub-agent versus a full team?'
Release zoom
Comparison table: sub-agent vs team - 'A sub-agent is for one-off tasks, context gone. A team is back-and-forth'
'building on what the others did. That's the difference'
'And here's something nobody talks about. Just like your code accumulates technical debt, your Claude Code setup does too'
Key concept callout - the hidden maintenance cost
'Skills get outdated. Agents reference old patterns. Instructions contradicting each other'
'Something 3 months ago now wrong, AI following old instructions instead of new ones'
SCREEN 09: MAINTAINING.md scrolling through - '346-line document just for how to maintain the AI setup'
Number callout - maintenance doc size
'And sometimes Claude creates new shortcuts on its own. Noticed a workflow I kept repeating, made a command without me asking'
SLIDE 08: Timeline arrow - 'approve every edit, bypass, plan mode, just say it in plain English'
'Now I just say think about this first in plain English and it does'
'it even goes into plan mode itself. That's 4 different workflows in less than a year'
'4 different workflows in less than a year. Tutorial from 6 months ago = probably teaching you the old way'
Number callout - pace of change
Whoosh: Chapter transition - The Trap payoff
Base layer under chapter card 5

title: THE TRAP
subtitle: The thing that made everything worse
_note: Chapter 5 card - the trap payoff
'remember that one thing I said at the beginning? The one thing everyone recommends that made everything worse?'
SLIDE 09: Overloaded toolbox - too many MCP servers, confused AI in the middle
Punch on 'it's actually the opposite'
HOLD on 'You give Claude 40 tools and it doesn't know which ones to use. Quality goes down'
GIF: mind blown on 'Quality goes down' - ironic reaction
Release zoom
'Government project has 15 agents but didn't start with 15. Started with zero. Hit a wall, added one. Hit another wall, added another. Every single one earned its place'
Key principle callout - the trap payoff message
'Start with nothing. Add things only when you feel the pain of not having them'
'Less is more until it isn't. So that's 1,158 hours compressed'
SLIDE 10: Three steps - 1. Init and go > 2. Structure everything > 3. Build a system
'Then you structure everything. One folder per feature. Context files everywhere. Tasks inside the repo'
'always a human checking anything that goes to production. And eventually you build a system around it'
'Custom MCP servers when the generic ones don't cut it. Task agents instead of role agents'
'maintain that system the same way you maintain your code. The difference between 10 hours and 1,000 hours'
Punch on closing line
HOLD on 'isn't knowing more features, it's knowing which ones to ignore'
Shimmer: Closing line emphasis - the big takeaway
Release zoom
End CTA: 'If you want to see the actual repo structures, agent configs...I share all of that inside Claudify. Link in description. See you in the next one. Bye'

subtitle: Link in description
_note: End CTA overlay - synced to 'inside Claudify'
